name: Angle in a Semicircle
statement: An angle inscribed in a semicircle is a right angle.
formal: If AB is a diameter and C lies on the circle, then ∠ACB = 90°.
philosophy: This classic result connects circular geometry with orthogonality and triangle properties.

name: Cyclic Quadrilateral Angle Rule
statement: In a cyclic quadrilateral, opposite angles are supplementary.
philosophy: The angle structure of a cyclic quadrilateral reveals the relationship between arcs and linear angles.

name: Power of a Point (Chord Case)
statement: The products of the segments of two intersecting chords are equal.
formal: If chords AB and CD intersect at P, then PA·PB = PC·PD.
philosophy: Encodes a distance-preserving invariant when a point intersects a circle’s chords.

name: Power of a Point (Tangent-Secant)
statement: The square of the tangent segment equals the product of the secant’s external and full length.
formal: If PA is tangent, and PBC is secant, then PA² = PB·PC.
philosophy: Unifies tangents and secants in one invariant formula from a fixed external point.

name: Intersecting Chords Angle Rule
statement: The angle formed by intersecting chords is half the sum of the arcs they intercept.
philosophy: Connects linear angles to intercepted arcs. Useful in indirect angle chasing.

name: Tangent Perpendicular to Radius
statement: A tangent to a circle is perpendicular to the radius at the point of contact.
formal: If PT is tangent and O is center, then ∠OTP = 90°.
philosophy: Basic property of tangents, often used to define and construct right angles.

name: Angle Bisector Theorem
statement: In triangle ABC, if AD is the angle bisector of angle BAC and D lies on BC, then BD/DC = AB/AC.
formal: If AD is angle bisector, then (BD / DC) = (AB / AC).
philosophy: This theorem connects angle bisection to segment ratios and is often used in triangle length calculations.
